review.title: "Model and Run" Constraint Networks with a MILP Engine
review.abstract: Constraint Programming (CP) users need significant expertise in order to model their problems appropriately, notably to select propagators and search strategies. This puts the brakes on a broader uptake of CP. In this paper, we introduce MICE, a complete Java CP modeler that can use any Mixed Integer Linear Programming (MILP) solver as a solution technique. Our aim is to provide an alternative tool for democratizing the "CP-style" modeling thanks to its simplicity of use, with reasonable solving capabilities. Our contributions include new decompositions of (reified) constraints and constraints on numerical variables.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Modern MILP solutions, such as IBM CPLEX or Gurobi, can be defined as "model and run" systems [20]. They embed dynamic procedures to make simple models efficient [2]. Conversely, although CP is a declarative technology, CP users require considerable expertise to adequately model their problems. This expertise is required to select any MILP engine and formulate a search strategy that is the main component of the modeling phase. This could be the broader take-up of CP. In this paper, we present MICE, a simple API to solve CP models called from Java. Our goal is not to design a winner between classic, propagation-based CP solutions and MILP engines. Obviously, some problems are best solved by CP and other best solved MILP models.

sections.heading: 2 Tables, Arithmetic Constraints and Logical Operators
sections.text: It is not that we can agree on a model based on a model. (...) We are the domain union of a model. (...) We are the domain union of a model. (...) We are the domain union of a model. (...) We are the domain unit. (...) We are the domains. (...)

sections.heading: 4 Experiments and Conclusion
sections.text: This year it is more than ever before.

This puts the brakes on a broader uptake of CP. In this paper, we introduce MICE, a complete Java CP modeler that can use any Mixed Integer Linear Programming (MILP) solver as a solution technique. Our aim is to provide an alternative tool for democratizing the “CP-style” modeling thanks to its simplicity of use, with reasonable solving capabilities. Our contributions include new decompositions of (reified) constraints and constraints on numerical variables.
